intro: Carex consors, commonly known as the common sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes grass-like plants known as sedges. The plant typically grows in wetlands, marshes, and along the edges of ponds, thriving in moist to wet soil conditions. Its leaves are sword-shaped, upright, and often have a textured surface, while its flowering stems produce small, clustered spikes of greenish or brownish flowers. Carex consors plays an important ecological role by stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various invertebrates and birds.
